title: The Dangers of Google’s .zip TLD - Bobbyr - Medium

last_post.content:
A worked-out example of how the ".zip" domain that Google has opened to registrants can be used in phishing attacks. The URL with the @ sign, and the characters that look like forward-slashes but aren't, looks like it goes to Github to download a zip file, but it actually goes to a server the phisher has registereed with the address "v1.27.1.zip".

The trick can also be pulled with other TLDs, but the .zip domain may make the URL look more like an expected file download.

https://medium.com/@bobbyrsec/the-dangers-of-googles-zip-tld-5e1e675e59a5

Moreover, in all of these tasks, GPT-4's performance is strikingly close to human-level performance".

Sparks of Artificial General Intelligence: Early experiments with GPT-4

title: Evaluating Verifiability in Generative Search Engines

last_post.content:
"Furthermore, citation recall and precision are inversely correlated with fluency and perceived utility—the responses that seem more helpful are often those with more unsupported statements or inaccurate citation"

This is a recurring pattern I've found in my research as well. The more fluent an LLM is, the better it is at shortcut reasoning and generating cohesive text, but the worse it is at everything else.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

We got to be honest. A lot of people new to the Fediverse experience Mastodon almost like as @mattblaze@federate.social describes here.

People I know, very tech savvy, have a near allergic reaction to Mastodon’s UI. And you’re not going to convince them to be fans.

This is why I’m so hellbent on working with #Calckey devs to make it a better experience. @kainoa and others actually listen to feedback. Which is huge.

Sometimes things don’t go 100% the way I like them to but we’re making significant progress, and I hope https://calckey.social becomes a great showcase for what is possible on the Fediverse.

RE: https://federate.social/users/mattblaze/statuses/110380682264183219

Research Article
Knitted origami
Elizabeth L. Wilmer

"Techniques are presented for embedding horizontal, vertical, and45◦diagonal crease lines into garter stitch knitted fabric. While theseare mostly based on standard lace knitting stitches, the horizon-tal creases use double-cable-crossed elongated stitches in a non-standard way. This crease library suffices to knit a model of a squaretwist, a foundational origami tessellation unit."

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/epdf/10.1080/17513472.2023.2191572

"Science is a strong-link problem" gives terminology to something I'd flailed at previously. In essence "strong-link" problems are where you care about good stuff and can tolerate bad stuff; "weak-link" is where you can't tolerate bad stuff. Recommended. https://www.experimental-history.com/p/science-is-a-strong-link-problem

At long last, JupyterLab 4.0 has been released 🍾

This version brings better performance and improved accessibility, a new text editor based on CodeMirror 6, improved Search and Replace functionality, and optional Real Time Collaboration (RTC).

Install it with `pip install "jupyterlab==4.0.0"`

The @Jupyter team will soon publish a blog post and a new version of the classic Notebook. Stay tuned!

Full release notes https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/changelog.html

@ct_bergstrom [...]
To quote @pluralistic:
"The problem isn’t that the chatbots lie all the time — it’s that they usually tell the truth, but then they start spouting confident lies."
and:
"That means that when Google ingests and repeats a lie, the lie gets spread to more sources. Those sources then form the basis for a new kind of ground truth, a “zombie statistic” that can’t be killed, despite its manifest wrongness."

title: Yakkin’ About ChatGPT, with David Roth

last_post.content:
David Roth memorably described the job of neoliberal economists as finding "new ways to say 'actually, your boss is right.'" Not just your boss: for decades, economists have formed a bulwark against seemingly obvious responses to the most painful parts of our daily lives, from wages to education to health to shelter:

https://popula.com/2023/04/30/yakkin-about-chatgpt-with-david-roth/

title: Coastal Cities Priced Out Low-Wage Workers. Now College Graduates Are Leaving, Too.

last_post.content:
"#SuperstarCities" like New York and San Francisco have long been priced out of the reach of working people, but now they're becoming unattainable for double-income, childless, college-educated adults in their prime working years:

https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/05/15/upshot/migrations-college-super-cities.html

A city that you can't live in is a failure. A system that can't provide decent housing is a failure. The "your boss is right, actually" crowd won: we don't build public housing, we don't regulate rents, and it suuuuuuuuucks.

A couple of blog posts on pharmacokinetic models that I hadn't gotten around to sharing before:

https://blog.djnavarro.net/non-compartmental-analysis/

https://blog.djnavarro.net/stan-ode/

The first one talks about non-compartmental analysis and has some very simple R code, the second one dives a little deeper and talks about compartmental models - which often require you to use an ODE solver in the model - in Stan and R.

I'm still learning pharmacokinetics so they're a little rough around the edges

#rstats

A couple of blog posts on pharmacokinetic models that I hadn't gotten around to sharing before:

https://blog.djnavarro.net/non-compartmental-analysis/

https://blog.djnavarro.net/stan-ode/

The first one talks about non-compartmental analysis and has some very simple R code, the second one dives a little deeper and talks about compartmental models - which often require you to use an ODE solver in the model - in Stan and R.

I'm still learning pharmacokinetics so they're a little rough around the edges

#rstats

title: That moment when you’re nodding off is a sweet spot for creativity

last_post.content:
"During the phase when you’re drifting between sleep and waking, a state known as sleep onset, the creative mind is particularly fertile, the researchers showed. They also demonstrated, for the first time, that when people are prompted to dream about a particular topic during that sleep phase, they perform much more creatively when later asked to perform three creativity tasks around that topic."
#creativity #dream #conscious

https://news.mit.edu/2023/sleep-sweet-spot-dreams-creativity-0515

title: OpenAI CEO calls for laws to mitigate ‘risks of increasingly powerful’ AI

last_post.content:
I welcome the clear call for regulation by Gary Marcus and Sam Altman in front of Congress. One of the many things that worry me is if the regulation is used to shut out smaller players, who don't have the financial strength of a Microsoft. Universities, NGOs, start ups, and individual developers shouldn't be shut off. This shouldn't be the "moat". Also, regulation isn't everything. Fair taxation of profits derived from humanity's commons should benefit all of humanity.

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/may/16/ceo-openai-chatgpt-ai-tech-regulations

title: Apple introduces new features for cognitive accessibility, along with Live Speech, Personal Voice, and Point and Speak in Magnifier

last_post.content: These are pretty extraordinary accessibility improvements that Apple just launched, and like all such fixes, make things better for *everyone*. I can think of so many people in my life I'd want to enable some of these features for, and also wish I'd had access to some of these as just the last few years I've dealt with everything from cognitive impairment to vision issues; so far they've all been temporary, but of course that will change. https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/05/apple-previews-live-speech-personal-voice-and-more-new-accessibility-features/

My article, "Origins of the U.S. Genre-Fiction System, 1890–1956" is now out in Book History.

https://doi.org/10.1353/bh.2023.0006

Open-access preprint:

If you want to know what's so special about 1956, you'll have to read the essay, or at least the blog post:
